trans-unit.source: Enhance your API App for Logic Apps
trans-unit.target: Enhance your API App for Logic Apps

trans-unit.source: In this article, you'll learn how to define the API definition of your API app so that it works well with Logic Apps.
trans-unit.target: In this article, you'll learn how to define the API definition of your API app so that it works well with Logic Apps.

trans-unit.source: This will enhance the end user experience for your API app when it is used in the Logic Apps designer.
trans-unit.target: This will enhance the end user experience for your API app when it is used in the Logic Apps designer.

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: If you are new to <link><linkText>API apps</linkText><title></title></link> in <link><linkText>Azure App Service</linkText><title></title></link>, we recommend reading the multi-part series on <link><linkText>creating API apps</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: If you are new to <link><linkText>API apps</linkText><title></title></link> in <link><linkText>Azure App Service</linkText><title></title></link>, we recommend reading the multi-part series on <link><linkText>creating API apps</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: Add Display Names
trans-unit.target: Add Display Names

trans-unit.source: The Logic Apps designer displays the names of operations, fields, and parameters, which may at times be cumbersome to read as they are programmatically generated.
trans-unit.target: The Logic Apps designer displays the names of operations, fields, and parameters, which may at times be cumbersome to read as they are programmatically generated.

trans-unit.source: To improve readability, the Logic Apps designer can, where it is available, display a more readable text value - known as a display name - instead of the operation, field, and parameter default names.
trans-unit.target: To improve readability, the Logic Apps designer can, where it is available, display a more readable text value - known as a display name - instead of the operation, field, and parameter default names.

trans-unit.source: To accomplish this, the Logic Apps designer scans for the presence of certain properties in the swagger metadata provided by your API app.
trans-unit.target: To accomplish this, the Logic Apps designer scans for the presence of certain properties in the swagger metadata provided by your API app.

trans-unit.source: The following properties are used as display names:
trans-unit.target: The following properties are used as display names:

trans-unit.source: Operations (Action and Triggers)
trans-unit.target: Operations (Action and Triggers)

trans-unit.source: The value of the summary property if present; otherwise the value of operationId property.
trans-unit.target: The value of the summary property if present; otherwise the value of operationId property.

trans-unit.source: Note that the Swagger 2.0 specification allows for up to 120 characters for the summary property.
trans-unit.target: Note that the Swagger 2.0 specification allows for up to 120 characters for the summary property.

trans-unit.source: Parameters (Inputs)
trans-unit.target: Parameters (Inputs)

trans-unit.source: The value of the x-ms-summary extension property if present; otherwise the value of the name property.
trans-unit.target: The value of the x-ms-summary extension property if present; otherwise the value of the name property.

trans-unit.source: The x-ms-summary extension property must be set dynamically in code.
trans-unit.target: The x-ms-summary extension property must be set dynamically in code.

trans-unit.source: That process is described in the "Using Custom Attributes to annotate extension properties" section of this topic.
trans-unit.target: That process is described in the "Using Custom Attributes to annotate extension properties" section of this topic.

trans-unit.source: The name property can be set using /// comments.
trans-unit.target: The name property can be set using /// comments.

trans-unit.source: That process is described in the "Using XML Comments in API Definition generation" section of this topic.
trans-unit.target: That process is described in the "Using XML Comments in API Definition generation" section of this topic.

trans-unit.source: Schema Fields (Output Responses)
trans-unit.target: Schema Fields (Output Responses)

trans-unit.source: The value of the x-ms-summary extension property if present; otherwise the value of the name property.
trans-unit.target: The value of the x-ms-summary extension property if present; otherwise the value of the name property.

trans-unit.source: The x-ms-summary extension property must be set dynamically in code.
trans-unit.target: The x-ms-summary extension property must be set dynamically in code.

trans-unit.source: That process is described in the "Using Custom Attributes to annotate extension properties" section of this topic.
trans-unit.target: That process is described in the "Using Custom Attributes to annotate extension properties" section of this topic.

trans-unit.source: The name property can be set using /// comments.
trans-unit.target: The name property can be set using /// comments.

trans-unit.source: That process is described in the "Using XML Comments in API Definition generation" section of this topic.
trans-unit.target: That process is described in the "Using XML Comments in API Definition generation" section of this topic.

trans-unit.source: Note: It is recommended to keep the length of your display names to 30 characters or less.
trans-unit.target: Note: It is recommended to keep the length of your display names to 30 characters or less.

trans-unit.source: Using XML Comments in API Definition generation
trans-unit.target: Using XML Comments in API Definition generation

trans-unit.source: For development using Visual Studio, it is common practice to annotate your API controllers using <link><linkText>XML comments</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For development using Visual Studio, it is common practice to annotate your API controllers using <link><linkText>XML comments</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: When compiled with <link><linkText>/doc</linkText><title></title></link>, the compiler will create an XML documentation file.
trans-unit.target: When compiled with <link><linkText>/doc</linkText><title></title></link>, the compiler will create an XML documentation file.

trans-unit.source: The Swashbuckle toolset included with the API App SDK can incorporate those comments while generating the API metadata, and you can configure your API project to do that by following these steps:
trans-unit.target: The Swashbuckle toolset included with the API App SDK can incorporate those comments while generating the API metadata, and you can configure your API project to do that by following these steps:

trans-unit.source: Open your project in Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: Open your project in Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: From the Solution Explorer, right-click the project and select Properties.
trans-unit.target: From the Solution Explorer, right-click the project and select Properties.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Project Properties</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Project Properties</linkText>

trans-unit.source: When the project's property pages appear, perform the following steps:
trans-unit.target: When the project's property pages appear, perform the following steps:

trans-unit.source: Select the Configuration for which the settings will apply.
trans-unit.target: Select the Configuration for which the settings will apply.

trans-unit.source: Typically, you will select All Configurations so that the settings you specify apply to both Debug and Release builds.
trans-unit.target: Typically, you will select All Configurations so that the settings you specify apply to both Debug and Release builds.

trans-unit.source: Select the Build tab on the left
trans-unit.target: Select the Build tab on the left

trans-unit.source: Confirm that the XML documentation file option is checked.
trans-unit.target: Confirm that the XML documentation file option is checked.

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio will supply a default file name based on your project's name.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio will supply a default file name based on your project's name.

trans-unit.source: You can set its value to whatever your naming convention requires or leave it as-is.
trans-unit.target: You can set its value to whatever your naming convention requires or leave it as-is.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Set XML Doc property</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Set XML Doc property</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Open the SwaggerConfig.cs file (located in the project's App_Start folder).
trans-unit.target: Open the SwaggerConfig.cs file (located in the project's App_Start folder).

trans-unit.source: Add using directives to the top of the SwaggerConfig.cs file for the System and System.Globalization namespaces.
trans-unit.target: Add using directives to the top of the SwaggerConfig.cs file for the System and System.Globalization namespaces.

trans-unit.source: Search the SwaggerConfig.cs file for a call to GetXmlCommentsPath, and uncomment the line so that it executes.
trans-unit.target: Search the SwaggerConfig.cs file for a call to GetXmlCommentsPath, and uncomment the line so that it executes.

trans-unit.source: Since you have not yet implemented this method, Visual Studio will underline the call to GetXmlCommentsPath and indicate that it's not defined in the current context.
trans-unit.target: Since you have not yet implemented this method, Visual Studio will underline the call to GetXmlCommentsPath and indicate that it's not defined in the current context.

trans-unit.source: That's okay.
trans-unit.target: That's okay.

trans-unit.source: You'll implement it in the next step.
trans-unit.target: You'll implement it in the next step.

trans-unit.source: Add the following implementation of the GetXmlCommentsPath method to the SwaggerConfig class (defined in the SwaggerConfig.cs file).
trans-unit.target: Add the following implementation of the GetXmlCommentsPath method to the SwaggerConfig class (defined in the SwaggerConfig.cs file).

trans-unit.source: This method will simply return the XML documentation file you specified earlier in the project's settings.
trans-unit.target: This method will simply return the XML documentation file you specified earlier in the project's settings.

trans-unit.source: Finally, specify the XML comments for your controller methods.
trans-unit.target: Finally, specify the XML comments for your controller methods.

trans-unit.source: To do this, open one of your API app's controller files and type /// on an empty line preceding a controller method you want to document.
trans-unit.target: To do this, open one of your API app's controller files and type /// on an empty line preceding a controller method you want to document.

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio will automatically insert a commented section within which you can specify a method summary as well as parameter and return value information.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio will automatically insert a commented section within which you can specify a method summary as well as parameter and return value information.

trans-unit.source: Now, when you build and publish your API app, you'll see that the documentation file is also in the payload and uploaded with the rest of your API app.
trans-unit.target: Now, when you build and publish your API app, you'll see that the documentation file is also in the payload and uploaded with the rest of your API app.

trans-unit.source: Categorize Advanced Operations and Properties
trans-unit.target: Categorize Advanced Operations and Properties

trans-unit.source: The Logic Apps designer has limited screen real estate for showing operations, parameters, and properties.
trans-unit.target: The Logic Apps designer has limited screen real estate for showing operations, parameters, and properties.

trans-unit.source: Additionally, an API App can define an extensive set of operations and properties.
trans-unit.target: Additionally, an API App can define an extensive set of operations and properties.

trans-unit.source: The result of so much information being displayed in a small area can result can make using the designer difficult for the end-user.
trans-unit.target: The result of so much information being displayed in a small area can result can make using the designer difficult for the end-user.

trans-unit.source: To mitigate this clutter, the Logic Apps designer allows you to group the API app's operations and properties into user-defined categories.
trans-unit.target: To mitigate this clutter, the Logic Apps designer allows you to group the API app's operations and properties into user-defined categories.

trans-unit.source: By using a proper categorization of the operations and properties, an API app can improve the user experience by presenting the most basic and useful operations and properties first.
trans-unit.target: By using a proper categorization of the operations and properties, an API app can improve the user experience by presenting the most basic and useful operations and properties first.

trans-unit.source: To provide this ability, the Logic Apps designer looks for the presence of a specific custom vendor extension property in the swagger API definition of your API App.
trans-unit.target: To provide this ability, the Logic Apps designer looks for the presence of a specific custom vendor extension property in the swagger API definition of your API App.

trans-unit.source: This property is named x-ms-visibility and can take the following values:
trans-unit.target: This property is named x-ms-visibility and can take the following values:

trans-unit.source: empty or "none"
trans-unit.target: empty or "none"

trans-unit.source: These operations and properties are readily viewable by the user.
trans-unit.target: These operations and properties are readily viewable by the user.

trans-unit.source: "advanced"
trans-unit.target: "advanced"

trans-unit.source: As these operations and properties are advanced, they are hidden by default.
trans-unit.target: As these operations and properties are advanced, they are hidden by default.

trans-unit.source: However, the user can easily access them if needed.
trans-unit.target: However, the user can easily access them if needed.

trans-unit.source: "internal"
trans-unit.target: "internal"

trans-unit.source: These operations and properties are treated as system or internal properties and not meant to be directly used by the user.
trans-unit.target: These operations and properties are treated as system or internal properties and not meant to be directly used by the user.

trans-unit.source: As a result, they are hidden by the designer, and available only in the Code View.
trans-unit.target: As a result, they are hidden by the designer, and available only in the Code View.

trans-unit.source: For such properties, you may also specify the x-ms-scheduler-recommendation extension property to set the value through the Logic Apps designer.
trans-unit.target: For such properties, you may also specify the x-ms-scheduler-recommendation extension property to set the value through the Logic Apps designer.

trans-unit.source: For an example, refer the article on <link><linkText>adding triggers to an API App</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For an example, refer the article on <link><linkText>adding triggers to an API App</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Using Custom Attributes to annotate extension properties
trans-unit.target: Using Custom Attributes to annotate extension properties

trans-unit.source: As mentioned above, custom vendor extension properties are used to annotate the API metadata to provide richer information that the Logic Apps designer can use.
trans-unit.target: As mentioned above, custom vendor extension properties are used to annotate the API metadata to provide richer information that the Logic Apps designer can use.

trans-unit.source: If you use static metadata to describe your API app, you can directly edit the /metadata/apiDefinition.swagger.json in your project to manually add the necessary extension properties.
trans-unit.target: If you use static metadata to describe your API app, you can directly edit the /metadata/apiDefinition.swagger.json in your project to manually add the necessary extension properties.

trans-unit.source: For API apps that use dynamic metadata, you can make use of custom attributes to annotate your code.
trans-unit.target: For API apps that use dynamic metadata, you can make use of custom attributes to annotate your code.

trans-unit.source: You can then define an operation filter in the SwaggerConfig.cs file to look for the custom attributes and add the necessary vendor extension.
trans-unit.target: You can then define an operation filter in the SwaggerConfig.cs file to look for the custom attributes and add the necessary vendor extension.

trans-unit.source: This approach is described in detail below for dynamically generating the x-ms-summary extension property.
trans-unit.target: This approach is described in detail below for dynamically generating the x-ms-summary extension property.

trans-unit.source: Define an attribute class called CustomSummaryAttribute that will be used to annotate your code.
trans-unit.target: Define an attribute class called CustomSummaryAttribute that will be used to annotate your code.

trans-unit.source: Define an operation filter called AddCustomSummaryFilter that will look for this custom attribute in the operation parameters.
trans-unit.target: Define an operation filter called AddCustomSummaryFilter that will look for this custom attribute in the operation parameters.

trans-unit.source: Edit the SwaggerConfig.cs file and add the filter class defined above.
trans-unit.target: Edit the SwaggerConfig.cs file and add the filter class defined above.

trans-unit.source: Use the CustomSummaryAttribute class to annotate your code, as shown in the following code snippet.
trans-unit.target: Use the CustomSummaryAttribute class to annotate your code, as shown in the following code snippet.

trans-unit.source: When you build the above API app, it would generate the following API metadata:
trans-unit.target: When you build the above API app, it would generate the following API metadata:

trans-unit.source: Similarly, you can define schema filter AddCustomSummarySchemaFilter to automatically annotate the x-ms-summary extension property for your schema models, as in the following example.
trans-unit.target: Similarly, you can define schema filter AddCustomSummarySchemaFilter to automatically annotate the x-ms-summary extension property for your schema models, as in the following example.

trans-unit.source: Summary
trans-unit.target: Summary

trans-unit.source: In this article, you have seen how to enhance the user experience of your API app when it is used in the Logic Apps designer.
trans-unit.target: In this article, you have seen how to enhance the user experience of your API app when it is used in the Logic Apps designer.

trans-unit.source: As a best practice, it is recommended that you provide proper friendly names for all operations (actions and triggers), parameters and properties.
trans-unit.target: As a best practice, it is recommended that you provide proper friendly names for all operations (actions and triggers), parameters and properties.

trans-unit.source: It is also recommended that you provide no more than 5 basic operations.
trans-unit.target: It is also recommended that you provide no more than 5 basic operations.

trans-unit.source: For input parameters, the recommendation is to restrict the number of basic properties to no more than 4, and for properties, the recommendation is 5 or less.
trans-unit.target: For input parameters, the recommendation is to restrict the number of basic properties to no more than 4, and for properties, the recommendation is 5 or less.

trans-unit.source: The remainder of your operations and properties should be marked as advanced.
trans-unit.target: The remainder of your operations and properties should be marked as advanced.

trans-unit.source: test
trans-unit.target: test
